div.head: Corroding and dissolving absolutely pure gold
div.ab: Put it regular salt with aqua fortis into a violl. Let it rest for two hours, without heating it. Put in this mixture tenuous gold, and draw it out as if it had been separated from silver.

div.head: Engraving on iron
div.ab: One ℥ of verdigris and 2 ℥ of coarse salt & a bit of sublimate, or crush some ocher with linseed oil, and use it to cover the blade or the very neat & polished iron. & let it dry on the fire or in the sun. Then, to engrave & make it beautiful, take a small coin's worth of verdigris & twice that quantity of coarse salt & about four grains of ammoniac, & six grains of sublimate, & the water must not be hot.

div.head: Good mixture to color gold
div.ab: Sulphur & small gravel as much of one as of the other, & the third part of this quantity of salt, & as much turmeric as sulphur.

div.head: How to silver plate copper and latten
div.ab: Mold the silver as the gold, & put it in the oven in order to get a good gilt pot. And do not let it heat, otherwise the silver would tarnish. Once it will be well spread, make it boil in walnut oil, & then heat it a bit, & put it into the water the silversmiths use to bleach their works.

div.head: Enameling a carnelian
div.ab: Soak some wheat flour in white wine, and slop & cover the whole carnelian. Then cook the violet again, then soak it into white wine for one or two hours, then rub it & leave the part you want to keep on it, then lay on some more on top again.
